description: From Middle English gon, goon, from Old English gān (“to go”), from Proto-West Germanic *gān, from Proto-Germanic *gāną (“to go”), from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰeh₁- (“to leave”).
The inherited past tense form yode (compare Old English ēode) was replaced through suppletion in the 15th century by went, from Old English wendan (“to go, depart, wend”).

entries.meaning: (postpositive, chiefly military and space flight) Working correctly and ready to commence operation; approved and able to be put into action.
examples: John Glenn reports all systems are go.

entries.meaning: (uncommon) The act of going.
examples: The Apostles were to be the first of a line. They would multiply successors, and the successors would die and their successors after them, but the line would never fail; and the come and go of men would not matter, since it is the one Christ operating through all of them.

entries.meaning: A turn at something, or in something (e.g. a game).
examples: Synonyms: stint, (turn in a game) turn, (turn in a game) move, turn
You’ve been on that pinball machine long enough—now let your brother have a go.
It’s your go.

entries.meaning: An attempt, a try.
examples: Synonyms: attempt, bash, shot, stab, try
I’ll give it a go.

entries.meaning: An approval or permission to do something, or that which has been approved.
examples: Synonym: green light
We will begin as soon as the boss says it's a go.

entries.meaning: An act; the working or operation.
examples: Let this suffice, that that same happy night,  So gracious were the goes of marriage  […]

entries.meaning: (slang, dated) A circumstance or occurrence; an incident, often unexpected.
examples: “Well, this is a pretty go, is this here! An uncommon pretty go!

entries.meaning: (dated) The fashion or mode.
examples: Synonyms: mode, style, trend
quite the go

entries.meaning: (dated) Noisy merriment.
examples: a high go

entries.meaning: (slang, archaic) A glass of spirits; a quantity of spirits.
examples: Synonyms: gage, measure

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Power of going or doing; energy; vitality; perseverance.
examples: Synonyms: energy, flair, liveliness, perseverance, pizzazz, spirit, verve, vigour, vim, vitality, zest
There is no go in him.

entries.meaning: (cribbage) The situation where a player cannot play a card which will not carry the aggregate count above thirty-one.
A period of activity.
examples: ate it all in one go

entries.meaning: (obsolete, British slang) A dandy; a fashionable person.
examples: See Thesaurus:dandy

verbs.description: go (third-person singular simple present goes, present participle going, simple past went or (archaic) yode, past participle gone or (nonstandard) went)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move through space (especially to or through a place). (May be used of tangible things like people or cars, or intangible things like moods or information.)
examples:
I have to go now.
Audio (US)(file)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move or travel through time (either literally—in a fictional or hypothetical situation in which time travel is possible—or in one's mind or knowledge of the historical record). (See also go back.)
examples: You have to go all the way back to Herbert Hoover to see a performance in the Standard & Poors 500 equal to what we are experiencing right now.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To navigate (to a file or folder on a computer, a site on the internet, a memory, etc).
To move (a particular distance, or in a particular fashion).
examples: We've only gone twenty miles today.
This car can go circles around that one.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move or travel in order to do something, or to do something while moving.
examples: We went swimming.
Let's go shopping.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leave; to move away.
examples: Synonyms: depart, leave, exit, go away, go out
Antonyms: come, arrive, approach
Please don't go!
I really must be going.
Workmen were coming and going at all hours of the night.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To walk; to travel on one's feet. [11th–19th c.]
examples: ‘As for that,’ seyde Sir Trystram, ‘I may chose othir to ryde othir to go.’

entries.meaning: (intransitive, chiefly of a machine) To work or function (properly); to move or perform (as required).
examples: Synonyms: function, work, operate
The engine just won't go anymore.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To start; to begin (an action or process).
examples: Get ready, get set, go!
On your marks, get set, go!
On your marks, set, go!
Here goes nothing.
Let's go and hunt.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take a turn, especially in a game.
examples: Synonyms: move, make one's move, take one’s turn
It’s your turn; go.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To attend.
examples: I go to school at the schoolhouse.
She went to Yale.
They only go to church on Christmas.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To proceed (often in a specified manner, indicating the perceived quality of an event or state).
examples: That went well.
"How are things going?" "Not bad, thanks."

entries.meaning: (intransitive, colloquial, with another verb, sometimes linked by and) To proceed (especially to do something foolish).
examples: Why'd you have to go and do that?
Why'd you have to go do that?
He just went and punched the guy.

definitionGroups.group: To follow or travel along (a path):

entries.meaning: To follow or proceed according to (a course or path).
examples: Let's go this way for a while.
She was going that way anyway, so she offered to show him where it was.

entries.meaning: To travel or pass along.
(intransitive) To extend (from one point in time or space to another).
examples: This property goes all the way to the state line.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lead (to a place); to give access to.
examples: Does this road go to Fort Smith?

entries.meaning: (copulative) To become. (The adjective that follows usually describes a negative state.)
examples: Synonyms: become, turn, change into
You'll go blind.  The milk went bad.
I went crazy.
After failing as a criminal, he decided to go straight.
The video clip went viral.
Don't tell my Mum: she'll go ballistic.

entries.meaning: To assume the obligation or function of; to be, to serve as.
examples: There is scarcely a business man who is not occasionally asked to go bail for somebody.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To continuously or habitually be in a state.
examples: I don't want my children to go hungry.
We went barefoot in the summer.

entries.meaning: (copulative) To come to (a certain condition or state).
examples: They went into debt, she goes to sleep around 10 o'clock.
the local shop wants to go digital, and eventually go global.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change (from one value to another) in the meaning of wend.
examples: The traffic light went straight from green to red.

entries.meaning: To turn out, to result; to come to (a certain result).
examples: How did your meeting with Smith go?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To tend (toward a result).
examples: Well, that goes to show you.
These experiences go to make us stronger.

entries.meaning: To contribute to a (specified) end product or result.
examples: qualities that go to make a lady / lip-reader / sharpshooter

definitionGroups.group: To pass, to be used up:

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of time) To elapse, to pass; to slip away. (Compare go by.)
examples: The time went slowly.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To end or disappear. (Compare go away.)
examples: Synonyms: disappear, vanish, go away, end, dissipate
Antonyms: remain, stay, hold
After three days, my headache finally went.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be spent or used up.
examples: His money went on drink.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To die.

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive, cricket) To be lost or out:

entries.meaning: (intransitive, cricket, of a wicket) To be lost.
(intransitive, cricket, of a batsman) To be out.
(intransitive) To collapse or give way, to break apart.
examples: Synonyms: crumble, collapse, disintegrate, give way

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To break down or decay.
examples: My mind is going.
She's 83; her eyesight is starting to go.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be sold.
examples: The car went for five thousand dollars.
The store is closing down so everything must go.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be discarded or disposed of.
examples: This chair has got to go.
All this old rubbish can go.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be given, especially to be assigned or allotted.
examples: The property shall go to my wife.
The award went to Steven Spielberg.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To survive or get by; to last or persist for a stated length of time.
examples: Against the Big Green, Princeton went the entire first and third quarters without gaining a first down,  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive, sports) To have a certain record.
examples: They've gone one for three in this series.
The team is going five in a row.

definitionGroups.group: To be authoritative, accepted, or valid:

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have (final) authority; to be authoritative.
examples: Whatever the boss says goes, do you understand?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be accepted.
examples: Anything goes around here.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be valid.

definitionGroups.group: To say (something), to make a sound:

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To say (something, aloud or to oneself). (Often used in present tense.)
examples: I go, "As if!" And she was all like, "Whatever!"
As soon as I did it, I went "that was stupid."

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make the (specified) sound.
examples: Cats go "meow". Motorcycles go "vroom".

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sound; to make a noise.
examples: At 4pm, the phone went. It was The Sun: 'We hear your daughter's been expelled for cheating at her school exams […] 'She'd made a remark to a friend at the end of the German exam and had been pulled up for talking.As they left the exam room, she muttered that the teacher was a 'twat'. He heard and flipped—a pretty stupid thing to do, knowing the kids were tired and tense after exams. Instead of dropping it, the teacher complained to the Head and Deb was carpeted.

entries.meaning: To be expressed or composed (a certain way).
examples: The tune goes like this.
As the story goes, he got the idea for the song while sitting in traffic.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To resort (to).
examples: I'll go to court if I have to.

definitionGroups.group: To apply or subject oneself to:

entries.meaning: To apply oneself; to undertake; to have as one's goal or intention. (Compare be going to.)
examples: I'm going to join a sports team.
I wish you'd go and get a job.
He went to pick it up, but it rolled out of reach.
He's going to leave town tomorrow.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make an effort, to subject oneself (to something).
examples: You didn't have to go to such trouble.
I never thought he'd go so far as to call you.
She went to great expense to help them win.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To work (through or over), especially mentally.
examples: I've gone over this a hundred times.
Let's not go into that right now.

definitionGroups.group: To fit (in a place, or together with something):

entries.meaning: (intransitive, often followed by a preposition) To fit.
examples: Synonyms: fit, pass, stretch, come, make it
Do you think the sofa will go through the door?
The belt just barely went around his waist.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be compatible, especially of colors or food and drink.
examples: Synonym: harmonize
Antonym: clash
This shade of red doesn't go with the drapes.
White wine goes better with fish than red wine.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To belong (somewhere).
examples: Synonyms: belong, have a place
My shirts go on this side of the wardrobe.
This piece of the jigsaw goes on the other side.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To date.
examples: Synonyms: go out (with), date, see
How long having they been going together?
He's been going with her for two weeks.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To (begin to) date or have sex with (a particular race).
(intransitive) To fight or attack.
examples: I went at him with a knife.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete, US, slang) To fight.
(transitive, Australian slang) To attack.
examples: Then I′m sure I heard him mutter ‘Why don′t you get fucked,’ under his breath.
It was at that moment that I became a true professional. Instead of going him, I announced the next song.

entries.meaning: To be in general; to be usually;   often in comparison to others of the same group.
examples: As sentences go, this one is pretty boring.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take (a particular part or share); to participate in to the extent of.
examples: Let's go halves on this.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To yield or weigh.
examples: Those babies go five tons apiece.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To offer, bid or bet an amount; to pay.
examples: That's as high as I can go.
We could go two fifty.
I'll go a ten-spot.
I'll go you a shilling.
I'll go him one better.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To enjoy. (Compare go for.)
examples: I could go a beer right about now.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, colloquial) To urinate or defecate.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:urinate, see also Thesaurus:defecate
I really need to go.
Have you managed to go today, Mrs. Miggins?

entries.meaning: (imperative) Expressing encouragement or approval.
examples: Go, girl! You can do it!

description: From the Japanese 碁 (go), one character of the game's more usual Japanese name 囲碁 (igo), taken from the Chinese 圍棋 / 围棋 (wéiqí).

entries.meaning: (board games) A strategic board game, originally from China and today also popular in Japan and Korea, in which two players (black and white) attempt to control the largest area of the board with their counters.
examples: Synonyms: weiqi, baduk
